node.text: In a bid to chip away at the remaining hesitancy regarding makeup on men, we asked the makeup artist @RaisaFlowers to do a pair of video tutorials demonstrating looks that readers can, she hopes, easily replicate at home. In the one shown here, she realizes a look inspired by the 1998 film “Velvet Goldmine,” with shimmery purple eye shadow and translucent tinted lip balm. The overall effect is meant to be one of high-impact minimalism tempered with subtle playfulness. Visit tmagazine.com for more. Video by Justin French (@frenchgold), styled by @YohanaLebasi. #TBeautyIssue

node.title: Makeup for Men, or Anyone: Full-Face Glam

node.text: As part of T’s Beauty & Luxury issue, the writer @MeganEOGrady explores what makeup means to the growing group of men who have embraced it. Her piece is accompanied by photos of models with faces done by the makeup artist @RaisaFlowers, who, in a bid to make such adornment less intimidating, breaks down her process in a pair of video tutorials, demonstrating what she calls two “simplistic and masculine” looks that readers can, she hopes, easily replicate at home. In one video, she shares tips for creating dewy skin accented with a vivid swipe of color across the lids, and in another, she realizes a more classically glamorous visage with shimmery purple eye shadow and translucent tinted lip balm. The overall effect of both styles is a kind of high-impact minimalism tempered with subtle playfulness. See more on tmagazine.com. Video by Justin French (@frenchgold), styled by @YohanaLebasi. #TBeautyIssue

node.title: Minimal Makeup Looks for Men — or Anyone

node.text: A brief history of how New York’s Sag Harbor became a refuge for African-American families, with testimonials from some of the residents who’ve summered there for much of their lives. Read Sandra E. Garcia's (@s_evangelina) accompanying story on this close-knit community on tmagazine.com. Video by @JoshuaKissi. Produced by Tom Delavan (@tdelavan).

node.title: Long Island's Enduring Black Beachfront Community

node.text: Flip your phone horizontally to watch this video: On Feb. 25 and 26, 2020, T gathered seven established black actresses — all of whom got their start decades ago, working across various mediums — for a group and cover shoot by the photographers @MickaleneThomas and @RacquelChevremont in Los Angeles, California. In it, these women — @HalleBerry, Angela Bassett (@im.angelabassett), @TarajiPHenson, Mary J. Blige (@therealmaryjblige), Lynn Whitfield (@mslynnwhitfield), @ViolaDavis and Kimberly Elise (@ikimberlyelise) — remember their first roles and discuss the solidarity they feel with one another. “We are living in an age in which some of our greatest, most successful actors are black women, near 50 or older, veterans who have fought against an industry that for much of its history would have rather ignored them,” writes @BrianKeithJackson in the accompanying story. Read more on Tmagazine.com. Video by @scottrossfilm.

node.text: Flip your phone horizontally to watch this video: On Oct. 15, 2018, T gathered 32 black American male poets, playwrights and novelists — writers whose work is so crucial to our understanding America itself — at the Brooklyn Historical Society for a group portrait creative directed by @BootsRiley and this accompanying short film by @YvonneMichelleShirley. In it, these men reflect on their experiences and quote from some of their favorite works by black female American writers, whose voices are equally powerful and necessary. As Audre Lorde once said, “We don't only write about ourselves, we use ourselves to illuminate something that we really believe and we really feel.” Read the accompanying story, and why we chose to focus specifically on black men for this piece, on Tmagazine.com. You’ll also find a reading list chosen by these men of their favorite black female writers.

node.title: On Being a Black Male Writer in America

node.text: Around the country, restaurants are expanding their menus of thoughtful, complex, nonalcoholic cocktails to keep pace — especially this month — with a population that’s drinking less. And while these drinks are made for adult palates, they’re also drawing an unexpected fan base: children. T hosted a taste test, inviting children of the magazine’s staff and writers to assess several mocktails at @ReceptionBar.NYC, a modern Korean spot on Manhattan’s Lower East Side. Video by @scottrossfilm.

node.text: The floral artist @JoshuaWerber creates three decorative arrangements using fruits, vegetables, herbs — and even weeds. Videos by @unitedlabor, music by @workplaywork. #TSummerEntertaining

node.title: How to Arrange Flowers for an Unexpected, Wild-Looking Table

node.text: The playwright #TerrenceMcNally, @AudraMcDonald and #MichaelShannon talked theater in celebration of McNally’s 80th birthday, their new Broadway production of #FrankieandJohnny, and T’s recent Culture issue. Moderated by Philip Galanes. #TimesTalks

node.title: Terrence McNally talks theater with @AudraMcDonald and Michael Shannon

node.text: Block Shop Textiles printer Mukesh Chhipa works on a paper block print in the village of Bagru.

node.title: Ancient Art of Block Printing in Jaipur

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by T: The NYTimes Style Magazine on August 18, 2021. May be an image of wrist watch.

node.text: At the turn of the 19th century, Western culture became fascinated with meteors and other astronomical phenomena. Around the same time, two men working 800 miles apart — the Austrian printer Count Alois von Beckh Widmanstätten and Guglielmo Thomson, an English mineralogist based in Naples — made a similar discovery: If one treats a split-open iron-based meteorite with a mild nitric acid solution, a strikingly intricate crystalline grid emerges. Today, the motif is referred to as the Widmanstätten patterns or the Thomson structures, but no matter who gets credit, they are among nature’s most hypnotic creations. Rolex, the Swiss watchmaker, has used meteorite for its dials in the past, backing thin slices of it with brass, but now, the company has reimagined its iconic Cosmograph Daytona with a face made from a solid slab of chemically treated fallen star. Written by Nancy Hass, photo by Esther Choi (@esthermchoi), styled by Todd Knopke (@todd_knopke).

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by T: The NYTimes Style Magazine on August 18, 2021. May be an image of indoor and brick wall.

node.text: #RoomOfTheDay: Vila Rica, Ilka Teodoro and Andre Venancio’s weekend house in Brazil, consists of two low-slung pavilions set in a landscape of grasses, brush and gnarled flowering trees indigenous to the area. Skylights and an interior garden bring the Cerrado — the country’s second-largest biome — into the primary bathroom, cocooned in red brick walls, cumaru wood ceilings and charcoal gray granite floors. Click the link in our bio for more. Photo by @JoanaFranca.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by T: The NYTimes Style Magazine on August 18, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and indoor.

node.text: Like many conceptual artists before her, Jade Kuriki-Olivo gained her reputation as something of a trickster, making a name as Puppies Puppies (@puppiespuppiesjade) while obscuring the identity behind the persona — what seemed both a canny marketing move and a kiss-off to the contemporary art world’s fixation on who’s who. Without biographical information, viewers were forced to contend with only the artist’s output, grounded in creative ventriloquisms. The artist’s exhibitions regularly featured a lone performer, often portraying a figure from children’s entertainment or a monstrous, if misunderstood, villain. But in late 2017, Puppies’ work began to engage biography as subject more explicitly. The first reference to Kuriki-Olivo’s gender transition appeared in “Green (Ghosts),” an installation for which she and her then partner, identified only as Forrest, relocated their apartment’s contents to Los Angeles’s Overduin & Co. gallery, where they and their dog would sleep each night, thus altering the space from day to day. In 2018, she created an installation that functioned as a funeral for her deadname, complete with a grass lawn and an engraved headstone. Click the link in our bio to read Jameson Fitzpatrick’s (@jmsnftzptrck) full story. Photo by Melody Melamed (@melodymelamedfoto), set design by Todd Knopke (@todd_knopke), makeup by Kaori Chloe Soda (@kaori_chloe_soda).

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by T: The NYTimes Style Magazine on August 17, 2021. May be an image of furniture and living room.

node.text: #RoomOfTheDay: By filling his 1830s Brooklyn Heights apartment with just the essentials, Colin King has created an oasis of calm. Here, an Astep VV Cinquanta pendant hangs over a Mario Bellini Le Bambole sofa, a Carl Auböck side table and a 1970s Isamu Noguchi lamp. On the mantle, assemblages by Dieter Crumbiegel and a 1950s Jacqueline Lerat fishbowl. Click the link in our bio for more. Written by Tom Delavan (@tdelavan), photographed by Blaine Davis (@blaineduh).

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by T: The NYTimes Style Magazine on August 17, 2021. May be art.

node.text: In the fourth century B.C., a Greek physician named Ctesias described an animal that would become known as the unicorn: a large, pale blue-eyed ass with a crimson head and a horn of white, red and black that would continue to find fresh interpretation over the generations. Today, unicorns canter through the works of Lewis Carroll and Shel Silverstein, out of “My Little Pony” and into the “Harry Potter” series. In 2017, the American fashion designer Thom Browne sent a gauzy puppet version down a Paris runway. It presides as Scotland’s national animal, emblematic of the country’s stubborn bravery. In Silicon Valley, the term “unicorn” symbolizes a billion-dollar start-up. In open sexual arrangements, a unicorn is a couple’s third lover. A recent show at Greene Naftali in New York by the German painter #JanaEuler (whose work is pictured here) offered a different interpretation: Her “Morecorns,” with their monstrously long snouts and multiple horns, recall deformed animals at a traveling circus — a novelty item, a way to sell tickets, their mutations the result of human intervention. Yet, why, precisely, does the unicorn persist in our collective imagination, and why does it feel especially relevant now? Click the link in our bio for Mallika Rao’s (@mallika.irl) take.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by T: The NYTimes Style Magazine on August 17, 2021. May be an image of indoor.

node.text: There are times, while perched in his attic studio in Rome, when the Italian artist @RobertoRuspoli imagines he’s Cosimo in Italo Calvino’s novel “Baron in the Trees,” a character who exchanges his predictable life of privilege for one of his own making in the treetops. Some evenings, the 1,000-square-foot space, with its skeletal pitched ceiling of centuries-old wooden beams, reminds him of an ancient boat, the kind on which Odysseus might have journeyed home to Ithaca. The painter and mural artist has called Paris home for the last few years, but whenever he needs inspiration, he returns to this place high in the rafters of his childhood home, a 19th-century townhouse near the Spanish Steps. “The space is literally a blank canvas,” says Ruspoli, who washed the apartment in a chalky hue so he could sketch on the walls. “Working here helps me to stay in a clean mental state where the shapes and forms in my head are pure.” Click the link in our bio to explore Ruspoli’s Rome studio. Written by Gisela Williams (@giselaatlarge), photo by Danilo Scarpati (@danilo.scarpati).

node.text: When T assembled a panel of architects, designers and journalists to create a list of the 25 most significant works of postwar architecture, we knew going into it that Times readers would have their own ideas about buildings that ought to have been included or omitted; even our jury members were cognizant of the inherent limitations of such an assignment. With that in mind, we put together an additional list of significant buildings erected since World War II, chosen based on a smattering of the wealth of comments we received on Instagram and on the original article itself, where many people rallied for the world’s most famous starchitects and others made passionate pleas for lesser-known works that personally moved them. Click the link in our bio to see which buildings — including ​​Frank Lloyd Wright’s Guggenheim Museum in New York, shown here in 1958 — Times readers thought should have made our list of #T25Buildings.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by T: The NYTimes Style Magazine on August 16, 2021. May be an image of outdoors, tree and brick wall.

node.text: When Ilka Teodoro and her husband, Andre Venancio, decided in 2014 to build a weekend house on five acres of former pastureland outside Sobradinho in Brazil, they knew, she says, “that we wanted it connected to the Cerrado and to Brasília, to the architecture of the city and its landscape.” To build the home, which the couple named Vila Rica, they commissioned Bloco Arquitetos, a Brasília-based firm founded in 2008 by Henrique Coutinho, Matheus Seco and Daniel Mangabeira, who met as architecture students at the University of Brasília. In the last decade, Bloco has made a name for itself designing restaurants, shops and private houses in the surrounding suburbs, the latter mostly composed of luminous white volumes raised against the blue scrim of the sky: geometric voids inspired by contemporary Portuguese architects like Álvaro Siza and Manuel Aires Mateus. According to Seco, whose family moved from Rio to Brasília when he was a child, the name of their firm references that shared aesthetic: In Portuguese, “a bloco can mean a concrete or ceramic brick — a basic element of construction,” he says, but in Brasília, the word “bloco” also refers to the residential buildings that form the city’s lived space, in contrast to Niemeyer’s ethereal monuments. For this project, though, Teodoro and the architects wanted to create something that would pay homage to not only Brasília but also the native countryside from which it was born. Click the link in our bio for more. Written by Michael Snyder (@mtpsnyder), photo by @JoanaFranca. #TWomenIssue

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by T: The NYTimes Style Magazine on August 15, 2021 tagging @drawingcenter. May be an image of indoor.

node.text: The pioneering Lebanese artist Huguette Caland died in 2019, at the age of 88, after a fertile five-decade career producing paintings, drawings, sculpture and fashion. Now @theDrawingCenter has mounted the first-ever museum exhibition of her oeuvre in the U.S., bringing together over 100 works on paper and canvas as well as caftans, sculptures and notebooks. The daughter of Bechara El-Khoury, postcolonial Lebanon’s first president, Caland moved to Paris in 1970 to pursue her art, leaving behind a husband and three children. There she made erotic line drawings of lovers, lips and vulvas; a series of stunning semi-abstract paintings suggestive of corporeal close-ups titled “Bribes de Corps” (“Body Parts”); and pictorially embroidered caftans. Click the link in our bio for more. Written by Will Fenstermaker. #TList

node.text: #RoomOfTheDay: In the main bathroom of the Hunting Season (@huntingseasonnyc) designer Danielle Corona’s home in Bogotá, Colombia, salvaged Calacatta marble covers the walls and floor. Photo by Simon Bosch (@simonboschphotographynl).

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by T: The NYTimes Style Magazine on August 14, 2021 tagging @cuyamabuckhorn. May be an image of road and text that says 'CUYAMA BUTK BUCKHORN'.

node.text: The salt flats and wildflower fields of Carrizo Plain National Monument in Santa Barbara County’s remote high desert are part of the spectacular scenery accessible from @CuyamaBuckhorn, a roadside motel-cum-wilderness resort that’s become a favorite base camp for explorers of the area’s natural beauty. Located nearly three hours northeast of Los Angeles in the historic town of New Cuyama, the property first opened in 1952 and was purchased three years ago by Ferial Sadeghian and Jeff Vance of the design firm iDGroup, who reimagined it with 21 guest rooms decorated with midcentury-modern furnishings. The latest additions include an outdoor theater and screening area, an open-air cooking school and cocktail bar, a dining space in an intimate greenhouse and a trifecta of exterior spa facilities: a heated pool, a Jacuzzi and a barrel sauna. Click the link in our bio for more. Written by @MichaelaTrimble. #TList
